	boundary="=====================_2192102==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Russia Enacts Sweeping Reforms in Drug Laws

--=====================_2192102==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Russia Enacts Sweeping Reforms in Drug Laws: No Jail for Possession
  5/14/04

DRCNet reported in March that Russia was on the verge of making dramatic 
reforms to its draconian drug laws after the Duma passed legislation that 
would remove criminal penalties and the possibility of jail time for simple 
drug possession. But then the wheels flew off the whole process as drug 
warriors within the Russian government attempted to turn the reform on its 
head by defining the quantities of each drug that would constitute 
possession for personal use at levels so low as to render the reforms 
meaningless, or worse. (Visit 
<http://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle/328/russia.shtml>http://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle/328/russia.shtml 
and 
<http://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle/329/russialaw.shtml>http://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle/329/russialaw.shtml 
for our earlier coverage.)

Now the drug warriors have been fought off, and reformers have managed to 
get quantities set at levels that will keep hundreds of thousands of 
Russian drug users out of prison. Under the old law, possession of even a 
single marijuana cigarette could garner a three-year prison sentence. 
According to Russian authorities, somewhere between 200,000 and 300,000 
people are currently serving time for drug offenses.

Under the new law -- actually an amendment to the Criminal Code -- which 
went into effect Wednesday, people possessing no more than 10 times the 
"average single dose" will no longer be charged with a crime, but an 
"administrative infraction." Possession of between 10 and 50 times the 
"average single dose" is punishable by a larger fine and community service, 
but again, no jail or prison time. Small-scale dealers will find themselves 
protected against drug trafficking charges by this second provision -- 
unless they get caught in the act of selling. Punishment for drug sales is 
increased under the new law.

Here are the critical quantity levels determined by the Russian government 
in consultation with drug reform groups such as the Russian Harm Reduction 
Network and the NAN Foundation. These are the quantities that represent ten 
times the "average single dose," up to which no one can be arrested or 
criminally charged:
heroin, 1.0 grams
cocaine, 1.5 grams
marijuana, 20.0 grams (dried)
hashish, 5.0 grams
ecstasy, 0.5 grams
methamphetamine, 0.5 grams
mescaline, 0.5 grams
LSD, 0.003 grams
psilocybin, 0.005 grams

The Russian equivalent of the DEA, the Federal Drug Control Service, wanted 
much lower levels, Vitaly Djuma, head of the Russian Harm Reduction 
Network, told DRCNet while the levels were being decided. "The agency 
responsible for setting new doses is the Ministry of Health," said Djuma, 
"but using its status as a state security agency, the Federal Drug Control 
Service (FDCS) tried to push through its own determinations where, for 
example, a single dose of heroin was 0.0001 gram, thus turning all drug 
users once again into 'drug dealers.' This could not only nullify the 
humanizing of legislation by the Russian administration but also directly 
threaten the safety -- and lives -- of millions of Russians who use drugs."

Under the quantities proposed by the FDCS, the "average single dose" of 
marijuana would be 0.0015 grams. With a standard joint weighing in at about 
one gram, possession of a single joint would make the possessor subject to 
penalties for drug dealing because one gram exceeds 50 doses (0.75 grams) 
by the FDCS standard. Similarly absurd low "average single doses" were set 
for other drugs as well.

But all that has been undone, and the FDCS is not happy. "Now drug addicts 
have the right to run around with their pockets full of marijuana, and we 
can't even detain them," FDCS deputy chief Alexander Mikhailov complained 
to the newspaper Kommersant Thursday. "The heroin dose is normal for a 
chronic drug user, but for a regular person it's nonetheless a dose of 
potassium cyanide. We were categorically against it, but the Justice 
Ministry simply went crazy chasing its European standards."

An FDCS spokesman was more diplomatic. "It's the law, and we are required 
to abide by it and enforce it," he told the Moscow Times Thursday.

Drug reformers welcomed the law and the new, improved "average single dose" 
levels. "This is a brave, humane law," said Lev Levinson, head of New Drug 
Policies, and one of the people who helped set the new quantities. "Now 
that police will stop persecuting users, they can start focusing on real 
threats like large-scale drug trafficking," he told the Times.

Now, if the Russians can only reign in the drug warriors. They were busy 
repressing the Moscow Million Marijuana March last weekend (see newsbrief 
this issue).

-- END --

http://stopthedrugwar.org/chronicle/337/russia.shtml




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

> fees.  it's called the "Save Bob Foundation".  there will be a sliding
scale of $0-$10 ( if you give $100, i'll dj for your events for free for
life, no joke)
>
> the party will run from 6pm-close.
> confirmed artists for the evening are:
>
> Michael the Redstickman (ambient mafia)
> Derek Fieldsoe (ambient mafia / 5families)
> DJ Lost (cosmic prod. / idos Music)
> Jonas Robledo (sf-vibe / 5families)
> with more TBA
>
> Please come by, celebrate, support permitted growers, patronize the
Sublounge, and watch me break dance.
>
> no, for real this time.
>
> love always,
> Jonas
>
> p.s. keep your eyes peeled for the supa-undaground "save bob foundation"
june 26th including Richard Summerhayes, Shanti, Marc Campbell, Jonas R.
and many more TBA
>

city of SF to the fine city on the other side of the bay, E-town!  (that's 
Emeryville y'all)  and to make things more fun and funky, we'll be having a 
bar for the 21+.  second, i'll have $7 presales on me at tonight at 
Gilligan's Island (Evil Breaks is hosting a room there) and Get Freaky.  
i'll have the tickets hidden somewhere on my body, it's up to you to find 
them.

i'm super pumped on this party!  i highly doubt any of you have been to this 
venue, and we are super stoked on the space.  spacious, comfy and to top 
things off, we've got some bad-ass breakbeats to smack your sweet patootie.  
come on out and join us!

Friday, May 21st

Hallucid

This event will be a small 250 capacity two room held in EMERYVILLE!!! The

strong from 9pm to 4am.

online at:

"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Yum... then after like 15 minutes of BB, he spun some Electro then electro Clash.... Then Pablo Gomez got on & spun alota Electro Clash also & some 80's (well.. 1 80's song (words by Tom Tom Club)

it was fun.. some dude from LA was there also takin' pictures & I'm gonna be on some photoalbum in this La groove site thingie... Hello 2day

Lastnight I went 2 this weeklie 2 this resuraunt bar place called Blaze.. Ooooooooh Yum!!!  Ok... there were these DJs there taggin' & stuff oh my goodness man... More Breakbeats... I Loved It!!  i was on the floor DMAO... it was Dope!!  I dunno any of the DJs who spun lastnight.. but it was just fun meeting all these groovy people lastnight...

OK.. well... 2morrow night i'm suppose 2 go 2 this this Breakbeats & Jungle event... OK.. Double Yum, so I'll repost 2morrow how that went...

Y'all have fun 2 the fashion show 2morrow!! =)

From sfraves-return-112586-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sat May 15 01:32:10 2004

Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v613)
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Message-Id: <9B95A632-A60B-11D8-A495-00050209EDF8@yahoo.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: John B. <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
Date: Fri, 14 May 2004 18:02:59 -0700
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.613)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: A rantish post about courtesy and respect for your host.

The following is basically a cut & paste of a rather long and rantish 
post I just dropped onto a thread over at bluelight.  Writing it, I got 
offtopic, and really started thinking about how much I WILL be 
OBLIGATED to adapt, change my ingrown ways, and give, to my hosts, that 
all-important part of plur: RESPECT.

The situation that lead to the bluelight thread:  1) Fancy-schmancy 
restaurant in Australia has a fancy-schmancy dress code.  2) Guy is 
denied service because he refuses to follow dress code (which applies 
to everybody, regardless of race, colour, or creed).  3) Guy decides 
that it is against his religion to follow dress code, and files 
complaint with government, claiming his human rights were violated.  4) 
Internet outrage ensues.  5) Someone mentions Japan, and I start to 
give a LOT more thought to what is going to be necessary to adapt to a 
living in a culture in which I was not raised.

So without further ado, John's rant about guests showing respect for 
their hosts:



It's funny that someone brought up Japanese culture, politeness, and 
respect; because it allows for a very easy demolition of all arguments 
against the restaurant.

Originally posted by -Thoth
 > Expecting otherwise is like being refused from a japanese restaraunt 
for wearing a
 > suit (sorry, it's rude! Kimonos only!)

As an american who is actually planning/hoping/preparing to move to 
Japan in about a year or so, I'd have absolutely no problem with this. 
If, on the other hand, I was denied service because I'm not Japanese, 
THEN I'd have some issues. See the difference? One is simple 
enforcement of a dress code, the other is discrimination.

But a FAR more apt example (since you brought Japanese culture into 
this) is not the kimono, it is the tradition that when you are entering 
a Japanese household, a nicer restaurant, or even some of the top-end 
Japanese restaurants here in the US, that you remove your shoes at the 
foyer. As a westerner, that is not my tradition. I'm not used to doing 
so, nor do I even usually think of doing it here. In fact, in many 
western households it is considered RUDE to remove your shoes at 
someone else's house, until you have passed a certain level of 
familiarity.

But if I make the move to Japan happen, when I am a guest in someone 
else's country, a guest in someone else's home, even a guest in someone 
else's restaurant; even though it is not MY tradition, do you think I 
will be taking my shoes off when I visit a Japanese home, or a 
restaurant nice enough that decorum requires it? You can bet your ass I 
will. It is the respectful and polite thing to do. And for me to do 
otherwise, for me to arrogantly and contemptuously disregard the 
culture that is playing host to me, would be inconceivably and 
unforgivably... well.... rude.

In a culture that places such a high emphasis on politeness and respect 
as Japan, I would probably always seem at least a bit uncouth. But that 
won't be for lack of trying.

Likewise, even though Japan has an educational system far superior to 
our own, and you can count on your average Japanese knowing some 
english (or at least, far more english than your average american knows 
Japanese); I will NOT be expecting to communicate in english when I get 
there. As a guest in their country, I fully expect to, and to have to, 
learn Japanese. In fact, I'm starting classes soon to get a head start 
in that regard.

A year or so ago, I was a (very) strict vegetarian. But in order to 
fully experience the culture, as so as not to take the chance of 
insulting anyone by turning my nose up at any dish I might be offered, 
I have already returned seafood to my diet (starting with sushi, of 
course). I've decided that, this being the experience of my lifetime, I 
will not miss out on ANYTHING, simply because of a silly dietary choice 
I made when I was a teenager. Suffice it to say, fugu is on the top of 
my list of "things to try" when I get there.

And I have been practically devouring books, websites, anything that 
might give me just a little bit more of an insight into the culture. 
Tops have been ones like "Culture Shock: Japan", and others that detail 
the more subtle differences that are not so obvious, but important if 
you want to be courteous and respectful of your hosts. No doubt, I'll 
make plenty of blunders. But I WILL be trying my very best to respect 
the culture that will so generously be my host.

*I* will adapt. As a guest, I will NOT expect or demand that my hosts 
change THEIR traditions and culture to service ME. To do otherwise 
would be so incredibly selfish, presumptuous, and flat out arrogant, 
that I just can't fathom myself being so obnoxiously disrespectful. 
Apparently, some people can, and do more than fathom themselves as that 
sort. And that's a shame.

I guess this entire thread would be moot, if only more people 
remembered an old saying. In fact, MY entire post could be summed up in 
the same saying. It starts out: "When in Rome...".


cya,
john

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] SFRCal 05.14.04


The answer is never the answer. What's really interesting is the mystery.
If you seek the mystery instead of the answer, you'll always be seeking.
I've never seen anybody really find the answer -- they think they have, so
they stop looking. But the job is to seek mystery, evoke mystery, plant a
garden in which strange plants grow and mysteries bloom. The need for
mystery is greater than the need for an answer. - Ken Kesey

--=20

Friday, May 14, 2004 ** Rich Medina & Sake One **

Rich Medina & Sake One
Rich Medina, was born and raised in New Jersey, is an artist who has exerci=
sed his opportunities to exploit his varied talents to the fullest. A poet,=
 DJ, producer, performer and model, Rich has emerged from the underground w=
ho's who, to the world of legitimate mass appeal and accomplishment.

Currently living in Philadelphia, Rich holds weekly DJ residencies in both =
Philadelphia and New York spinning hip-hop, house, neuvo soul, classic funk=
, rare grooves and afro beat to name a few. Rich still manages to find time=
 to host and co-own his own Internet radio show, The Dime Sack on Mediabure=
au.com as well as model for ECKO Unlimited, a leader in the urban apparel m=
arketplace.

As a DJ, Rich rocks hip-hop parties the old fashioned way, with good music =
that stands on its own. His house music and classic dance sets are reminisc=
ent of The Garage and all its pioneering fanfare prior to the age of the in=
dustry. As a lounge DJ, whether with neuvo soul or classic funk, there are =
not many who dig deeper for the ultimate in obscure vinyl bombs. From Phill=
y to Europe and beyond, Rich has shared his talents with true party people =
worldwide. Proof positive that music is a universal language, spoken and un=
derstood by all.

> WHO: DJ/Producers Garth and Jen=F6
>
> WHAT: Starting Sunday May 16th, the legendary Wicked party DJs and
> promoters
> explore their more eclectic tastes with Echo Beach at Bambuddha Lounge.
> "We've always been known for throwing in some old disco, funk, new wave,
> dubby trippiness or other unorthodox musical inspiration while we spin,"
> Jen=F6 says. "This party is an opportunity to pursue those other
> possibilities
> with more fervor as we will be expressing ourselves outside the accepted
> and
> usually quite safe musical formats of the current SF club scene."
> Pulling from their extensive collections of underground disco, soul, jazz
> and r&b, adding a bit of rock and reggae, this duo brings the funk San
> Francisco so desperately needs. More chilled than chaotic, the focus is
> hanging with old friends around the Phoenix Hotel's muraled pool, enjoyin=
g
> a
> Southeast Asian BBQ. Don1t arrive expecting the former space's infamous W=
et
> parties - although the tunes will be the most soul-soothing musical
> backdrop
> on a lazy Sunday, the music won't be beaten over your head.
> "We don't really have a musical policy as such, as pretty much anything
> goes,2 says Jen=F6.=A0 3Personally, I'm definitely looking to challenge m=
yself,
> expand my repertoire and take some risks musically."

t only party.

Ghostribe room

dj ghost - a true,original,renegade dj out of sf, he has been rocking crowd=
s for 15years from here to london and is the creator of ghostribe and has t=
hrown such wicked events as acid breaks, plastik and five. ghost and frank =
nitty also became known for there 4 table sets as the darkside 2 at most ho=
mebase events........ dont miss this rare apperance as he comes out of the =
shadows to bang some oldschool tracks from techno and breaks to drum and ba=
ss.

ming out for a one night only apperance to play some of the orginal breaks =
and jungle tracks that threw massive crowds into breakbeat bliss.

for over 10 years with a unique funky deep house breakbeat sound. he is a t=

r the bay area ............. if you are in the know then you know there is =
only one kwashi.

Thursday, June 24, 2004 ** Fuzion Presents 100% Tony Humphries, A Bay Area =
Exclusive **

House music has evolved from the soulful, gospel-inspired sounds of disco, =
and it owes its emergence to the artistry of DJ Tony Humphries. His unmista=
kable style continues to leave an irreplaceable impression on the global da=
nce music industry having entertained at over 500 venues worldwide and prod=
ucing more than 200 studio remixes. Throughout tremendous recognition, nume=
rous awards and accolades from his peers, Tony Humphries has remained humbl=
e and true to the sound of what we call house music.

Please join us for this special one night engagement, with Djs Tony Humphri=
es, David Harness, Matt Mau and Bernard Cabigon. At =93Mighty=94 Located in=
 the heart of the SF design district, within blocks of both Hwy 101 and Hwy=
 280, Mighty boasts a 6,000 square foot expanse of beautiful hardwood floor=
s, 22=88 high ceilings, exposed brick walls, and gigantic wood pillars and =
beams throughout. Sound system comes to Mighty from the legendary Sound Fac=
tory in New York City. It is a classic Richard Long & Associates system wit=
h most of the original components lovingly restored for the venue.

Administrative Notes
-------------------------------------------------

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week.

To subscribe to the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or
sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

At 05:32 PM 5/14/2004, you wrote:
>hey all

>so there was a co. protection one security systems that basically offered 
>me a job today as a tech/installer guy. . .

>the manager dude told me they do the testing right there with a cotton 
>swab that I rub inside my cheek. . .

>now thats new to me, I was all prepped for a urine test. . .
>
>does anyone know how the swab deal works ? how far back does the test go, 
>like if I smoked 2 weeks ago, would it show posistive ? or is more of a 
>recent activity test ? Does things like regular gargling with 
>listerine/peroxide effect it ?

The Bush administration yesterday proposed overhauling the way it conducts 
drug testing of more than 400,000 federal employees who hold sensitive 
positions. The invasive proposal is particularly harmful because it is 
expected to become the model for how private employers test prospective and 
current employees.

The <http://samhsa.gov/hottopics/click_drugtesting.html>proposed guidelines 
would allow the government to test employees' hair, sweat, and saliva for 
the presence of illegal drugs. The government says these tests are more 
accurate than urine testing. The irony of this claim is not lost on critics 
of drug testing, who point out that the Bush administration is pointing to 
the failures of federal urine testing while also launching a $23 million 
campaign to push drug testing of kids' urine in the nation's schools.

Critics, including the Drug Policy Alliance, have long argued that drug 
testing is an unconstitutional invasion of privacy. Though billed as a 
kinder, gentler means of testing than urine collection, hair, sweat, and 
saliva tests are no less problematic and are prone to similar failures 
because they can produce a false positive or be fooled by products already 
on the market designed to beat the tests. For instance:
    * Saliva tests can only detect drugs used within the last three days. A 
host of products claim to be able to help drug users beat the test.
    * Detoxification shampoos currently on the market claim to be able to 
rid hair follicles of the presence of drugs.
    * Sweat tests can register a false positive on someone who has been in 
a room where marijuana was being smoked.
The Multi Drug Saliva Test is a drug testing device that detects six drugs 
of abuse:
    * Marijuana (THC)
    * Cocaine (COC)
    * Opiates (OPI)
    * Amphetamine (AMP)
    * Methamphetamine (mAMP)
    * Phencyclidine (PCP)

The test uses the preferred lateral flow immunoassay technology for test 
screening and requires no special training. The qualitative yes/no test 
results are visibly obtained within several minutes.

And, there are a number of products out there that claim to beat the test:

http://www.passyourdrugtest.com/kits/saliva-test.htm



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

	I mostly mentioned Hilary as a prominent Washington D.C. Democrat. The

the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon don't seem to be 
making fine distinctions about American politics. Even if they were, 
Hilary Clinton might still be on their hit list. She was of course 
First Lady in the Clinton administration, which pursued many of the 
same policies as the Bush administration.

	In her own political career running for office and as a Senator, 
Hilary  has been supportive of Israel herself (perhaps more out of 
pandering to the Jewish vote in New York than from any personal 
conviction), voted for and still supports the war in Iraq, and has even 
called the U.S. volunteer military "inadequate," indicating she 
supports a draft.

	From an April 21 CNN story (see 
http://www.cnn.com/2004/ALLPOLITICS/04/21/iraq.hillary/):

"To the disappointment of some antiwar liberals in her Democratic base, 
Clinton, the former first lady, voted in favor of the Iraq war 
resolution in October 2002.

'Obviously, I've thought about that a lot in the months since," she 
said. "No, I don't regret giving the president authority because at the 
time it was in the context of weapons of mass destruction, grave 
threats to the United States, and clearly, Saddam Hussein had been a 
real problem for the international community for more than a decade.'"

	I mostly agree with that statement, but that's beside the point. Even 
though I think she and her husband deserve to go to jail for a long 
time for many reasons including probable involvement in mafia-style 
murders (see for example http://www.prorev.com/WWDEATH.HTM), the 
assassination of Hilary Clinton would not solve anything and I don't 
have any particular desire to see her dead.

    now thats new to me, I was all prepped for a urine test. . .

    does anyone know how the swab deal works ? how far back does the =
test go, like if I smoked 2 weeks ago, would it show posistive ? or is =

    aK=20



  The Bush administration yesterday proposed overhauling the way it =
conducts drug testing of more than 400,000 federal employees who hold =
sensitive positions. The invasive proposal is particularly harmful =
because it is expected to become the model for how private employers =
test prospective and current employees.
  =20
  The proposed guidelines would allow the government to test employees' =
hair, sweat, and saliva for the presence of illegal drugs. The =
government says these tests are more accurate than urine testing. The =
irony of this claim is not lost on critics of drug testing, who point =
out that the Bush administration is pointing to the failures of federal =
urine testing while also launching a $23 million campaign to push drug =
testing of kids' urine in the nation's schools.
  =20
  Critics, including the Drug Policy Alliance, have long argued that =
drug testing is an unconstitutional invasion of privacy. Though billed =
as a kinder, gentler means of testing than urine collection, hair, =
sweat, and saliva tests are no less problematic and are prone to similar =
failures because they can produce a false positive or be fooled by =
products already on the market designed to beat the tests. For instance: =

    a.. Saliva tests can only detect drugs used within the last three =
days. A host of products claim to be able to help drug users beat the =
test.=20
    b.. Detoxification shampoos currently on the market claim to be able =
to rid hair follicles of the presence of drugs.=20
    c.. Sweat tests can register a false positive on someone who has =
been in a room where marijuana was being smoked.=20
  The Multi Drug Saliva Test is a drug testing device that detects six =
drugs of abuse:=20
    a.. Marijuana (THC)=20
    b.. Cocaine (COC)=20
    c.. Opiates (OPI)=20
    d.. Amphetamine (AMP)=20
    e.. Methamphetamine (mAMP)=20
    f.. Phencyclidine (PCP)=20

  The test uses the preferred lateral flow immunoassay technology for =
test screening and requires no special training. The qualitative yes/no =
test results are visibly obtained within several minutes.

  And, there are a number of products out there that claim to beat the =
test:

  http://www.passyourdrugtest.com/kits/saliva-test.htm



  Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
                 =20

http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

tyranny a good conscience."
  -Albert Camus

the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually =
become visible."
  -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the =
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, =
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to =
that..."
  -Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

hey one thought tho. .

if these terrorists somehow posted the decapitation on the internet. . .
what, do they have like an aol account or a earthlink account or something ?
Could I search aol's members and find "evil terrorists" ?

could the ip's and such be tracked back to the terrorists ? Do they have DSL
in Iraq ? Well I guess from idlez post, they do, or were going to anyways. .
.yknow if thats the case. . .who's supplying the terrorists with evil
internet access ? Wouldn't that be a near equivalent to supplying them with
guns ? It sounds like the iraqis are a lil more pc proficient than the us
military. . .

I have one friend in the army who emails me occasionally with her cell phone
number thats a 707 area code, but she's supposedly in hawaii or something
right now. . .

did anyone see the news last night where 4 more american soldiers were
killed, 2 in battle and 2 when they flipped their jeep (prolly racing or
something)? Funny/sad how these highly trained military personnel end up
dying cuz they can't drive safely. . .I wonder if they got medals ? And I
wonder what the letters to their parents stated ? Valiant death avoiding a
protected species of  desert tortoise ?

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

15 Anomalies Surrounding
Death Of Nick Berg
What Really Happened.com
5-14-4

(Warning: Parts of the following discussion contain rather sickening 
references.)

Arab linguists have said the man posing as the Jordanian Zaraqawi did not 
speak with a Jordanian dialect. Others have suggested the man reading the 
written statement may not have been a native speaker of Arabic.

Zaraqawi was missing one leg and had been outfitted with an artificial leg 
that did not fit or function properly. He was unable to walk or stand 
normally with his ill-fitting limb. No man in the group showed evidence of 
such an infirmity.

Numerous indigenous sources have said Zaraqawi was killed by a US 
helicopter attack months ago when he was unable to move quickly enough to 
escape the targeted house. While others managed to exit the house in time 
to survive, he died in the collapsed building.

As any surgeon will testify, the alleged beheading was a fake. A beheading 
would result in a tremendous amount of spurting blood. There would have 
been blood everywhere had an actual beheading taken place. When the 
executioner holds up Berg's head immediately following what is represented 
as an actual decapitation of a living person, there is no significant blood 
flow from the neck or blood splatters showing anywhere on the executioner. 
Furthermore, the cut was simply too neat to have been done crudely and with 
such amazing speed by a man wielding a knife. Anybody who has ever carved a 
turkey knows there is something wrong with the supposed beheading. The 
suspended head looks more like Berg had been neatly beheaded by a guillotine.

The orange jumpsuit was standard US military issue to men in custody. It is 
unlikely Berg would have continuing wearing a US custodial uniform if he 
had been released by the military as they claim. The fact he was still 
wearing the suit is both anomalous and suggestive. One is forced to 
speculate as to whether there was an immediate transfer of Berg from the US 
military to unknown persons, thusly preventing Berg from discarding his US 
prison garb.

Several of the men in the film were fat by Iraqi standards. If they were 
Feyadeen or mujahadeen, they probably have been living underground since 
the first days of the occupation. Tens of thousands of Iraqis have been 
shown on news stories as they have marched and demonstrated. One would be 
hard pressed to point out a single fat man among these thousands.

Some men had what can only be described as pasty-white hands. Once again, 
one would be hard pressed to find Arab men with pasty-white hands.

The lack of spurting blood suggests Berg was already dead at the time of 
the alleged decapitation. It is possible Berg's dead body was displayed 
with his head already partially or totally severed. In any case, he almost 
certainly was killed before the staged beheading. If so, it suggests the 
captors had no stomach for an actual beheading of a living person, and they 
opted to fulfill their assignment quietly and with the least amount of gore.

The scream that is heard has been interpreted as a woman's scream by many 
viewers. Videotape cognoscenti have further said the scream was 
amateurishly added to the tape.

The U.S. government translation of one statement made on the film is: "Does 
al Qaeda need any further excuses?" This is a falsification. The actual 
statement urged fellow insurgents to get off their hind ends and do 
something. One assumes the translator being used by the US military is a 
native speaker of Arabic, so this cannot be explained as an innocent flub. 
This suggests the US government wanted to inject an alleged al- Qaeda group 
into the murder of Nick Berg.

Iraqis who have seen the videotape on Arabic news broadcasts are 
universally saying the men in the film are not Iraqis. Are they saying this 
partly because the speaker does not employ an Iraqi dialect? Where does 
their certainty come from?

Firearms experts have stated the AK-47 carried by one man was a "Gilal." 
This actually is an Israeli-made weapon that improves on the famous AK- 47. 
Feyadeen and other insurgents almost universally use AK-47s.

The man in the videotape who is purported to be Zarqawi is wearing a gold 
ring. This is absolutely proscribed by Islamic law.

The US military has stated that Berg was never in US custody and that he 
had been in custody of the Iraqi police. The Iraqi police adamantly deny he 
was ever in their custody. On April 1, an e-mail from Beth A. Payne, the 
U.S. consular officer in Iraq, was sent to the family of Nick Berg. It 
stated that Ms. Payne had located Nick, and he was currently in custody of 
the US military. We have to conclude that either the email was bogus or the 
US military has been lying.

The chair that Berg was seated in during the filming was a standard issue 
military chair of the exact same kind as seen in a color photo taken at the 
Abu Ghraib Prison. The chances a terrorist cell would be using this same 
chair are minimal at best.







Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: American Hostage Execution

I agree,

at first i didn't notice the guy moving much, but i watched it a couple more
times and saw him shrugging his shoulders and blinking. . .when they were
actually cutting his head off, his mouth opened and closed which could have
been from the cutting of the muscles/etc if he was already dead, but maybe
he was alive. . .if he was alive he was certainly not very active for a guy
getting his head cut off.

And the guy just had a reg old 8" or so knife. . .either he was really
really good at cutting off heads, or there was something fishy going on
there. I did notice blood (or a wet spot from something) on the floor, but
no spurting or dripping really at all that would show the guys heart was
still beating at the time his throat was cut. And wouldn't the killer have
to work a lil harder to cut thru the bones and such ?

 Maybe thats partially why it was on the internet and there wasn't any tape
found. . .internet connection issues and such made the video hard to see
clearly.

The times on the tape were interesting, you could see it jump from like
13something hours to around 2 while the guy was talking before the bad guys
speech. What else was recorded I wondered. . .it's obvious it was put
together in pieces tho.

the scream at the end suprised me. . .It didnt sound like a chick really,
and it didn't look at all like one of the captors screamed. . .you would
probably have noticed the guy taking a big breath or moving his mouth or
something. Plus, the scream sounded added on, like sounded clearer than the
rest of the sounds or from someone closer to the mic.

The way the guy read from the letter was odd to me. . .it didn't flow
properly like how someone would normally speak if they spoke and read any
language well. I don't know that language, but there were hardly any like
emphasized syllables, really monotone. Kind of looked like a school group
report to me.

And the way a couple of the guys were chilling with their guard totally
down. . .pulled their guns back, just stood there. . .I would think that
iraqi people would have all sorts of skin issues that would cause them to
itch occasionally, things from the desert atmosphere n such. But I didn't
see any there besides the guy wiping his nose or whatever he was doing.

plus it did look like they were all white guys. .. even the guy 2nd from the
right who kept touching his nose, you could see his face was white too.

And where do they buy their shoes ? It looked like the guy on the right had
on nike's or old airwalks, untied, which is odd cuz in a desert scenario
wouldn't he get lots of sand in his shoes ?. . .

One of the guys looked like he had an MP5 machine gun or something similar.
The other guy on the left seemed to try to cover up his gun.

hmmm. .. odd. . .

it's hard to tell with things like this, like who do you believe, either way
it could be the american government trying to cover their tracks. . .either
producing the video (I guess terrorists are good at editing and have the
tools for it lying around) or trying to cover up the video after it's
discovered.
Where do they plug the things in to charge the battery ? Do they use 120v
outlets in that country ?

aK

From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: American Hostage Execution


> 15 Anomalies Surrounding
> Death Of Nick Berg
> What Really Happened.com
> 5-14-4
>
> (Warning: Parts of the following discussion contain rather sickening
> references.)
>
> Arab linguists have said the man posing as the Jordanian Zaraqawi did not
> speak with a Jordanian dialect. Others have suggested the man reading the
> written statement may not have been a native speaker of Arabic.
>
> Zaraqawi was missing one leg and had been outfitted with an artificial leg
> that did not fit or function properly. He was unable to walk or stand
> normally with his ill-fitting limb. No man in the group showed evidence of
> such an infirmity.
>
> Numerous indigenous sources have said Zaraqawi was killed by a US
> helicopter attack months ago when he was unable to move quickly enough to
> escape the targeted house. While others managed to exit the house in time
> to survive, he died in the collapsed building.
>
> As any surgeon will testify, the alleged beheading was a fake. A beheading
> would result in a tremendous amount of spurting blood. There would have
> been blood everywhere had an actual beheading taken place. When the
> executioner holds up Berg's head immediately following what is represented
> as an actual decapitation of a living person, there is no significant
blood
> flow from the neck or blood splatters showing anywhere on the executioner.
> Furthermore, the cut was simply too neat to have been done crudely and
with
> such amazing speed by a man wielding a knife. Anybody who has ever carved
a
> turkey knows there is something wrong with the supposed beheading. The
> suspended head looks more like Berg had been neatly beheaded by a
guillotine.
>
> The orange jumpsuit was standard US military issue to men in custody. It
is
> unlikely Berg would have continuing wearing a US custodial uniform if he
> had been released by the military as they claim. The fact he was still
> wearing the suit is both anomalous and suggestive. One is forced to
> speculate as to whether there was an immediate transfer of Berg from the
US
> military to unknown persons, thusly preventing Berg from discarding his US
> prison garb.
>
> Several of the men in the film were fat by Iraqi standards. If they were
> Feyadeen or mujahadeen, they probably have been living underground since
> the first days of the occupation. Tens of thousands of Iraqis have been
> shown on news stories as they have marched and demonstrated. One would be
> hard pressed to point out a single fat man among these thousands.
>
> Some men had what can only be described as pasty-white hands. Once again,
> one would be hard pressed to find Arab men with pasty-white hands.
>
> The lack of spurting blood suggests Berg was already dead at the time of
> the alleged decapitation. It is possible Berg's dead body was displayed
> with his head already partially or totally severed. In any case, he almost
> certainly was killed before the staged beheading. If so, it suggests the
> captors had no stomach for an actual beheading of a living person, and
they
> opted to fulfill their assignment quietly and with the least amount of
gore.
>
> The scream that is heard has been interpreted as a woman's scream by many
> viewers. Videotape cognoscenti have further said the scream was
> amateurishly added to the tape.
>
> The U.S. government translation of one statement made on the film is:
"Does
> al Qaeda need any further excuses?" This is a falsification. The actual
> statement urged fellow insurgents to get off their hind ends and do
> something. One assumes the translator being used by the US military is a
> native speaker of Arabic, so this cannot be explained as an innocent flub.
> This suggests the US government wanted to inject an alleged al- Qaeda
group
> into the murder of Nick Berg.
>
> Iraqis who have seen the videotape on Arabic news broadcasts are
> universally saying the men in the film are not Iraqis. Are they saying
this
> partly because the speaker does not employ an Iraqi dialect? Where does
> their certainty come from?
>
> Firearms experts have stated the AK-47 carried by one man was a "Gilal."
> This actually is an Israeli-made weapon that improves on the famous AK-
47.
> Feyadeen and other insurgents almost universally use AK-47s.
>
> The man in the videotape who is purported to be Zarqawi is wearing a gold
> ring. This is absolutely proscribed by Islamic law.
>
> The US military has stated that Berg was never in US custody and that he
> had been in custody of the Iraqi police. The Iraqi police adamantly deny
he
> was ever in their custody. On April 1, an e-mail from Beth A. Payne, the
> U.S. consular officer in Iraq, was sent to the family of Nick Berg. It
> stated that Ms. Payne had located Nick, and he was currently in custody of
> the US military. We have to conclude that either the email was bogus or
the
> US military has been lying.
>
> The chair that Berg was seated in during the filming was a standard issue
> military chair of the exact same kind as seen in a color photo taken at
the
> Abu Ghraib Prison. The chances a terrorist cell would be using this same
> chair are minimal at best.
>

going to a packed party that just went off.

is definately older, burningman type crowd heavy.

missing what is proboboly the best club dance party experience SF
currently has to offer !!

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  How a secret Pentagon program came to Abu Ghraib.

--=====================_13299243==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

THE GRAY ZONE
by SEYMOUR M. HERSH
How a secret Pentagon program came to Abu Ghraib.
Issue of 2004-05-24
Posted 2004-05-15
The New Yorker

The roots of the Abu Ghraib prison scandal lie not in the criminal 
inclinations of a few Army reservists but in a decision, approved last year 
by Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld, to expand a highly secret 
operation, which had been focussed on the hunt for Al Qaeda, to the 
interrogation of prisoners in Iraq. Rumsfeld's decision embittered the 
American intelligence community, damaged the effectiveness of élite combat 
units, and hurt America's prospects in the war on terror.

http://www.newyorker.com/fact/content/?040524fa_fact




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: NIGHTLIFE - Saturday 5.29.04!!!

Sending an early notice for an upcoming event that we are throwing. We would
love it if all of you can make it out and show your support for local DJ's.
All the info about this party is posted below but if you would like to know
more about us and the party, please visit us at www.sfclubnightlife.com. On
the site you can register to be notified of future events and also get a
chance to be invited to the next event for FREE!! If you refer someone to us
and they register, you automatically get on our guest list for our next
event. Thank you for your time and we look forward to seeing you at
NIGHTLIFE and future events. We will be doing one more post for this party
prior to the event. Please forward this message to anyone who would love to
come out and hear a night of good house music.

Come experience San Francisco's
NIGHTLIFE
www.sfclubnightlife.com

Tony Hewitt (www.tangorecordings.com)
San Francisco (Tango / Nightshift / Detour)
There is no need for introduction here. Tony has been one of the staple
figures in the San Francisco scene for the last 10 years. Playing at all the
local events from The Gathering to Funky Techno Tribe. He tears up the floor
with his tough west coast house sound that we have all learned to love.
Check out Tony as he celebrates his latest release on Tango with the
"Company Three EP".

Jazz-e (www.jazz-e.com)
San Francisco (EMI / APG / Urbanloops)
With over 20 years experience Jazz-e began spinning at the ripe age of 9. He
blends a range of styles of house, vocal house, and techno. From funky
chunky to hard banging funk infused techno style beats with a touch of
breaks. He is a dj that knows how to motivate a crowd with uplifting music.
He has played all across the U.S. Canada, Mexico and the bay area, from
Spundae, Release, End-up, and many more. After a year of touring check him
out as he makes his first appearance in San Francisco in over a year.

Tim-e 
San Francisco (Universal Beat Co / KickDown)
Tim-E is a serious up and coming house dj from the bay area. He stands out
from the rest because of his versatility and his ability to read a crowd. He
does not just bring one sound to the decks like most dj's. He 
drops tracks that are funky, chunky, disco, tweaked out tribal, to your
deep, soulful, grooving house sounds. His ability to change styles and do it
well has caught the eyes of dj's and promoters alike.

NIGHTLIFE is held @ AsiaSF in San Francisco
AsiaSF is located @ 201 9th Street at the corner of 9th and Howard
Doors open at 10:00pm and goes till 3:00am, Entrance is $10.00
21 and up with full bar and upstairs lounge playing classic early 90's vocal
house =)))))
For more information please visit us online @ www.sfclubnightlife.com

Jordan,
info@sfclubnightlife.com
www.sfclubnightlife.com

hello, this is a continuation of a fictional piece:
 
ig was really, really, really, really, really grouchie.
"why are you such a grump today, ig?", asked supa baby.
"i think it is because i have not been getting laid." said ig.
"aren't you kind of young for that?" asked supa baby.
"well, i don't know. i just heard a man saying that he was a big grouch because he wasn't getting laid, and then a lady told him it was because he was a man and men are grouchie and have gas." said ig.
"oh, " said supa baby, "maybe you just have gas."
"maybe." said ig. :)

Subject: [sfraves] I went 2 a Phoenix Underground lastnight...Tumbleweeds

OK... so like all week that I been here so far, my new found Homie, Mi, been tellin' me abut this Jungle party happening on Sat that we could go 2 'cause y'all know how bad i need my Jungle fix across CA State Borders...

so Sat I got a new Tat that still has  2 filled, but it's nice, went 2 DJ record store in Tempe & got more info about the party, then went there!!

OK... @ 1st i dunno... we got there & there was this Dj spinning like breakbeats.. it was a good set, but he kept switching like tempos & it was almost hard 2 dance 2... then this House Dj went on next... it was Dope!!  he started spinning Tribal Funky House then did the rest of his set w/ Tech House & Hard House... it was fun.. 

Oh yeah... it was like a 2 room party in this Groovy Huge "virgin" warehouse... the other room was jus a chill room & they mainly played Ambient in there.. there was a point where the DJ busterd out some Dolphin Jungle 4 like 10 minutes... but totally went back 2 chill music...

then OK back in the main room... DJ SS from the UK got on the decks... goooooooooood shit man... I Loved it!!!  I danced my ass off!!!  he spun alot hard ass Dubby Jungle stuff & kept it onthe rest of his set w/ hella hard ass, bass bumpin, just stait evil Jungle!!  Loved it!!!

the vibe of the party was alright!!!  I mean... there were alota groovy friendly people there, but I dunno..., I guess I'm like totally on the unity thing & I dunno, i wasn't really feeling it... I mean.. I guess 'cause well... I only new a few people there who I've met fromt he weeklies I went 2 & the record store... but i dunno... I mean... it's something U can feel even if you're an outsider, right??  la la la  But yeah... I met aloooooota Awesome Groovers though! =)

Decorations were like totally minimal... they had like intella beams & like cardboard like cut outs of dessert plants & well... a store i think... but it was nice & minimal though, very Groovy!

It was Awesome 'cause there were like a few like booth/vendors there, face painting, water/popcorn booth, there were also a few others...

LoL.. there were people who like totally dressed up & stuff... some people were dressed up lke there were in a vegas show or like goin' 2 a fancy ballroom gala thingie... ohyeah... & the monsters from pac man were there also.. it was fun!

I met alot people here like totally want  me 2 come bacl 2 another party happeningherein like 2 weeks!!! Hmm... any1 down 4 a weekend road trip??? =) LoL

Take Care,
Peace-> O§bY {8O)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Looking for New York Lists

On Fri, May 14, 2004 at 01:46:05PM -0700, Happy wrote:
>    I'm going to New York in a week for a week long visit, and have been 
> trying, without much success, to find some local message boards or 
> mailing lists. The NYRaves page off of Hyperreal has events and a 
> calendar, but no mailing list. Does anyone know where I can look for 
> things rave related, especially if they are Jungle/DnB related?

I just moved to New York a few weeks ago and haven't found much yet
(granted, I haven't looked too hard). As for NYC Raves, go to the FAQ on
their site for mailing list info. Basically, use
nyc-raves-subscribe@hyperreal.org to subscribe. It's the same software
that's running sfraves, so all the same commands should work. The
nyc-raves list is pretty quiet though. There's not much stuff posted.

If you're interested in club nights (I don't think you'll find much else
in Manhattan itself), check out Camouflage at Guernica on Tuesday nights
(more info at http://www.camonyc.com/). They've got good DnB DJ's and a
great crowd (skip the main floor and go straight to the basement).
There's also DnB stuff going on other nights at various clubs. I don't
have the info handy, but let me know if you're interested and I'll dig
it up.

There's also a day rave happening on Saturday (5/22) with mostly techno
and hardcore. It looks promising :) Check out http://www.riotsound.com/
for more info on that.

gary

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: RE: [sfraves] saturday review: Ruby Sky - Behrouz

I have now been to Ruby Sky three times but this last one was the best.  The 
doorpeople are hella nice, and no 1015 vibe or strip searches.. and the 
people are pretty nice that go there.

Behrouz has really not been my favorite DJ to go see, but that man spins 
with everyone, and it seems like he is getting better each time I see him.  
On 5/28 he is spinning with Deepdish, and last time I saw him was with 
Oakenfold two months ago.  This was however a special night bacuase I got a 
free ticket for this event from his girlfriend and we spent the entire 
evening up on stage in the comfy bed right in front of the tables - dope!  I 
love a good vibe, I so rarely get to envibe*~:) these days and so chose 
saturday night to just let loose.. with an amazing new firend we set out on 
a beautiful journey, dancing, frolicing amoungst the crowd, and finally 
settling into the comfy spot.. the next time I looked up.. everyone was gone 
and it was 5am.. crap.. what a great nite.  I hope to go again for 
deepdish.. and Tiesto is spinng 6/4.. that is a must see.


SFR: Ranger
Santa Cruz
plurranger@hotmail.com
Who knows where the night leads
It's dark and no one can see

user scans a document or fax etc.. They want to be able to change some of 
the text in some or all of the document. They use to be able to do this when 
I had them hooked up to a multi function large scale printer,copier,fax 
unit. But we had some network issues and I can't get the scan function to 
work properly. So the user got a flat bed scanner from frys and when they 
scan something and try and change several different areas of the document 
they can make the first change succussfully but when they get to a second 
change they get the error: Could not complete your request because the 
pixels in a type. Layer cannot be edited without first rasterizing the 
layer.

The user has never seen that error and I dont know photoshop so I for sure 
dont know the error.

minupulate the total document at will.

Subject: [sfraves] ATP: New Jackie-T Mix up for ya!

------=_NextPart_000_00C0_01C43C28.03332B60
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hello friends, patrons and enemies ;)

Last weekend I finished my newest mixset, and low and behold it ended up =
being a double disk! j/k, this has been something I have been working on =
for a little bit now and I would like to share it with all of you.

Where can I get this, you ask? Visit www.jacktriumph.com and click on =
"downloads" after the main site pop's up. I will have "hardcopies" with =
me this Friday at Progression, available for a $3 "donation". All =
donations go to, and ONLY go to, reimbursing materials used for this =
project, (i.e. jewel cases, printing paper, discs, ink, etc.) Did you =
know you can't just go to office max and buy "2 disc" jewel cases?!?! =
Anyway, I don't wish to charge for it, but at the end of the day each =
"hardcopy" is running me about $2.73. And as I always I say; "That's =
Life".

And for those of you who say, I am not giving back to the artist? Well, =
I did. Every song on this album is from an actual piece of vinyl, no =
mp3's, cd's or any other digital technology used! So if it makes a =
difference to you, at approx. $10 per record, I spent well over $222 =
just to obtain the tracks to record this album (well being totally =
honest the "descent" tracks were both on the same album)  ;) But, being =
the diverse community you are, I can't imagine that being an issue. ;)

So, if you don't want to donate, the downloadable mp3's and album art =
are absolutely **FREE**, and personally that is how I would like to keep =
it. Just go to http://www.jacktriumph.com and click on "Downloads" - And =
as always, feedback is appreciated.

DJ Jack Triumph Presents: Humanitas Calleo
Disc 01 - Coepto
--
01 - Luke Chable "After The Storm"
02 - Moshic "The Myth of Osiris EP" Part 2
03 - Descent "Tempura"
04 - DPP "M3X1C0 Pt. 2" (Pavilian & Zimbardo Remix)=20
05 - 21st Century Fux  "Sunspirit" (Ivan Gough & Luke Chable's Oreo =
Breakbeat Remix)
06 - Quest "Bitter & Twisted" (Dirty Funktrain Mix)
07 - SDM Soundclash "Scream 2B Heard" (Remixed by Force Mass Motion)=20
08 - Scrambler "Free" (Lo Step's Class of '95 Remix)=20
09 - Moshic "The Myth of Osiris" Part 1
10 - Luke Chable & Jono Fernandez "Before You Break On Me"
11 - Bedrock "Emerald" (Grayarea Remix)

Disc 02 - Clausula
--
01 - Hambersham "Transparent Sound"
02 - Trafik "Your Light" (Luke Chable's Vocal Breaks Mix)
03 - UNKLE "In A State" (Meat Katie & Elite Force Remix)
04 - Descent "Round Midnight"
05 - Delerium "Truly" (Infusion Remix)
06 - Hybrid "Higher Than A Skyscraper" (Twitch + Sweat Mix)
07 - Blackwatch & Greed "Gentle Rain" (Grayarea's Dismembered Breaks =
Mix)
08 - Redanka "In A State" (FUcKed Vocal Mix)
09 - Stitch "Head To Head EP  - Stitch"
10 - EK "Keep It Casual"
11 - Leftfield "Dusted" (Tipper Remix)
--

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Jack Triumph" <jacktriumph@hotmail.com>
To: "SFRaves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, May 17, 2004 4:00 PM
Subject: [sfraves] ATP: New Jackie-T Mix up for ya!


Hello friends, patrons and enemies ;)

Last weekend I finished my newest mixset, and low and behold it ended up
being a double disk! j/k, this has been something I have been working on for
a little bit now and I would like to share it with all of you.

Where can I get this, you ask? Visit www.jacktriumph.com and click on
"downloads" after the main site pop's up. I will have "hardcopies" with me
this Friday at Progression, available for a $3 "donation". All donations go
to, and ONLY go to, reimbursing materials used for this project, (i.e. jewel
cases, printing paper, discs, ink, etc.) Did you know you can't just go to
office max and buy "2 disc" jewel cases?!?! Anyway, I don't wish to charge
for it, but at the end of the day each "hardcopy" is running me about $2.73.
And as I always I say; "That's Life".

And for those of you who say, I am not giving back to the artist? Well, I
did. Every song on this album is from an actual piece of vinyl, no mp3's,
cd's or any other digital technology used! So if it makes a difference to
you, at approx. $10 per record, I spent well over $222 just to obtain the
tracks to record this album (well being totally honest the "descent" tracks
were both on the same album)  ;) But, being the diverse community you are, I
can't imagine that being an issue. ;)

So, if you don't want to donate, the downloadable mp3's and album art are
absolutely **FREE**, and personally that is how I would like to keep it.
Just go to http://www.jacktriumph.com and click on "Downloads" - And as
always, feedback is appreciated.

DJ Jack Triumph Presents: Humanitas Calleo
Disc 01 - Coepto
--
01 - Luke Chable "After The Storm"
02 - Moshic "The Myth of Osiris EP" Part 2
03 - Descent "Tempura"
04 - DPP "M3X1C0 Pt. 2" (Pavilian & Zimbardo Remix)
05 - 21st Century Fux  "Sunspirit" (Ivan Gough & Luke Chable's Oreo
Breakbeat Remix)
06 - Quest "Bitter & Twisted" (Dirty Funktrain Mix)
07 - SDM Soundclash "Scream 2B Heard" (Remixed by Force Mass Motion)
08 - Scrambler "Free" (Lo Step's Class of '95 Remix)
09 - Moshic "The Myth of Osiris" Part 1
10 - Luke Chable & Jono Fernandez "Before You Break On Me"
11 - Bedrock "Emerald" (Grayarea Remix)

Disc 02 - Clausula
--
01 - Hambersham "Transparent Sound"
02 - Trafik "Your Light" (Luke Chable's Vocal Breaks Mix)
03 - UNKLE "In A State" (Meat Katie & Elite Force Remix)

one of the last sunsets i went to i called the "allergy sunset".  they 
went ahead and got a permit once again for berkeley marina, just like 
back in the old days.  just fine.  the problem was, they didn't do it 
in the grassy cove facing the water like they normally did.  they did 
it on the other side of the hill, where all the ragweed or whatever 
kind of plants those are they have over there.  so i spent most of the 
time there sneezing.  i stayed a few hours because of that and finallyh 
ended up having to flee in search of a hot bath.

i like those ones they do out there in lake champlain out there in 
novato.  those ones are good.

-d

giuki+sfraves@realify.com wrote:

>On Fri, May 14, 2004 at 01:46:05PM -0700, Happy wrote:
>  
>
>>   I'm going to New York in a week for a week long visit, and have been 
>>trying, without much success, to find some local message boards or 
>>mailing lists. The NYRaves page off of Hyperreal has events and a 
>>calendar, but no mailing list. Does anyone know where I can look for 
>>things rave related, especially if they are Jungle/DnB related?
>>    
>>
>
>I just moved to New York a few weeks ago and haven't found much yet
>(granted, I haven't looked too hard). As for NYC Raves, go to the FAQ on
>their site for mailing list info. Basically, use
>nyc-raves-subscribe@hyperreal.org to subscribe. It's the same software
>that's running sfraves, so all the same commands should work. The
>nyc-raves list is pretty quiet though. There's not much stuff posted.
>
>If you're interested in club nights (I don't think you'll find much else
>in Manhattan itself), check out Camouflage at Guernica on Tuesday nights
>(more info at http://www.camonyc.com/). They've got good DnB DJ's and a
>great crowd (skip the main floor and go straight to the basement).
>There's also DnB stuff going on other nights at various clubs. I don't
>have the info handy, but let me know if you're interested and I'll dig
>it up.
>
>There's also a day rave happening on Saturday (5/22) with mostly techno
>and hardcore. It looks promising :) Check out http://www.riotsound.com/
>for more info on that.
>
>gary
>

On Mon, 17 May 2004, innocentchild wrote:
-&e->The music was fine and pretty usual for Pacific Sound. The weather sucked
-&e->nuts. That was by far the worst sunset I've been to in 4 years weather wise.
-&e->Nothing like getting sand blasted constantly to make a day *grate* =P

I wouldn't say the music was average, Rebecca Watkins brought the fucking
funk in a way that was not too typical of Sunset at all.  Great alignment
with the sun dropping behind the DJ too.  Plus my friend Herb and I had
spent all day outside skating, and actually rode from the Richmond out to
Sunset... very fun day.  While the rest of SF went Bay to Breakers we
skated from Beach to Bay with stops in GG park, a quick bus ride over a
hilltop, some chow in the Haight, and got to ride all of Cesar Chavez
through that long descent after the Evans bridge thanks to a
freak break in traffic.

I have sunburn on my neck and my legs are jello.  :)
andyw

Subject: RE: [sfraves] BSP: 052104 MASH-UP

i know, it's kind of lame for me to reply to a BSP for my own party, but i'm 
going to do it anyway!

although the flyer says Mash-Up will be in SF...in fact, it will be in the 
east bay a very short hop, skip and jump from the base of the bay bridge.  
now, sometimes last minute venue changes end up being a bad thing...but in 
this case, luck was on our side and i'm very, very excited about this new 
space!

Mash-Up is going down in a very spacious studio/warehouse.  high ceilings, 
clean bathrooms, indoor smoking area, two large rooms of music and comfy 
sofas and chairs to sit on when your feet get sore cause you were shaking it 
too hard on the dance floor.

before this party even happens, i'd like to thank Mike and the Ambient Mafia 
for providing the beats for the chill room.  when the idea came up for a 
second room of downtempo beats, this is the first group of folks i thought 
of.

and with that, i'd like to invite everyone to come on out!  we're providing 
the space and the music...but you provide the vibe and groovy goodness.

see ya there!

-------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.invibe.com/bam

Download the new mix online!
-------------

hello, as we sometimes do, this is a special chanson kind of day:
 
who knows who wrote this one? that is not actually a question being posed. it is just a statement:
 
"we build it up and build it up and build it up and now we're solid! solid as a rock! dodododododo...that's what this love is! the thrill is still hot, hot, hot, hot, hot..oooo, oooo,ooo...solid!...." okay also:
 
this song is totally worth mentioning for no particular reason...video, song, album, everything...think about duran duran's "girls on film"...it is the best, and makes 80's music not look so stupid, but still, must recommend avoiding 80's parties unless your true love is there or something like that, because as much as we all love laura brannigan and "gloria", we also are here for a very specific reason. :)

that if you try and download 'em between 7pm Sunday and sometime AM on
Monday, that shit ain't gonna work ;)

email lance@nedmc.com for more info.

   We have also opened up booking consideration for the event. Please =
send all promotional material and Cd's(no mp3 links will be accepted) =
to:

NEDMC Booking
4331 Farm House Lane
Fairfax, VA 22032

 =20

    In Washington D.C. on September 3rd through 6th 2004, the National =
EDM Conference will take place at the Omni Shoreham Hotel. We will be =
utilizing the entire space of the hotel to bring you the best possible =
environment to network with others in the EDM industry. We will be =
hosting all genres, from hip hop to hardcore, from house to industrial. =
As well, we will also be showcasing the newest technologies for the =
coming year and beyond, as well as offering seminars and focus groups to =
help dj's, producers, and gear manufacturer's push the envelope of music =
production and presentation.


********************************
to be removed from this list, please email info@nedmc.com with the =
subject: REMOVE

"Save Bob

foundation and enjoy a musical freak out in the

people like Bob NOT in jail. Please.

X-MSMail-Priority: Normal

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp - bob's story

yknow if he was doing it legally. . .

most people are recommended to have their growers certificate in the area
were the plants are grown. . .I do, my friends do, and the grower should
also  have the forms stating he's a caregiver for various patients within
view. . .

and for all the legal issues. . .ocbc has programs designed to help people
with issues like that (if they truly were doing it all legally). . .

when it comes to issues like that, you have to expect the coppers to try to
screw you in every way. . . so you have to protect yourself, and
realistically there are organizations there to protect you. . . I haven't
seen someone who was all properly registered and had the appropriate
paperwork who ever had to pay all these attorney fees and such, let alone
even have a case go to court (or worry about going to jail). . .

and if thats how it happened, it's illegal search and seizure unless he let
them in himself. . .it should get thrown out immediately anyways. . .

I would hope he had all the correct forms and such from the patients signing
their growing rights over to him as a caregiver. . .if he wasn't registered
as such, he's pretty much screwed on the "I was growing those for patients"
thing. And if that's the case, depending on where he lived, if he was over
the allowed flowering/vegetative plant limits by his local laws, than he's
screwed too. . .

in all honesty, and if he didn't have the proper info, forms n such. . .it's
kind of his own fault. . .You can't just jump into something like that
without doing the legal research. Cuz if he did, he most likely wouldn't be
having any of these problems. Someone can easily become a full time
caregiver legally if they go thru all the proper processes. Lots of people
are, I sell to clubs occasionally, but tend to donate most of the extra I
don't need to clubs.

I'm open about growing with cops or whoever, no reason to lie,(i know my
rights too) I'm not doing anything wrong, I have all my forms and
certificates n such in order. . .I'm never bothered by police, but am
waiting for the day I need to excersize my rights cuz of some pissed off
sheriff officer or whatever (if it ever happens). . . really if some cops
stormed my grow area, shot my pitt bulls, pulled my plants, then found out
it was all legal. . .I would be due some serious reimbursement.

theres too many people trying to make money off the "medical" thing in
non-admirable ways. But pretty much everyone who goes thru all the proper
channels never has to worry about it. . .

btw, if he was doing this all legally. . .why would he fear going into jail
? Why would he have to pay all these fees ?

sounds like a fishy excuse to me. . .

I recall a party a couple years ago for some guy who was in some sort of
debt due to his own negligence, forgot what it was called tho.didn't turn
out very well.

In my opinion, if he wasn't registered correctly, and was doing this
illegally. . .an event such as this would only hurt the real medical
initiative, showing support for someone who didn't follow the "rules", while
all of us others do. . .it just adds fuel to the fire for the people who try
to fight against the whole medical use issue and shut it down.And something
like that's caused from a few "bad apples" will hurt many many other
innocent persons, potentially taking away their right to their much needed
medicine because of other people's greed. . .

not to be mean, but the procedures are in place to protect true medical
users and caregivers from both authorities and people illegaly using the
medical issue as an excuse or shield. . .you can do it all legally. . . tons
of people do.


aK

> the 13th Bob had stayed home to do his laundry
> and left his basement door closed and unlocked,
> waiting for the buzzer to sound for the next load.
> All of a sudden, a swarm of cops chasing a crackhead
> who never came near Bob's house let
> themselves into his basement. Bob was
> cultivating (LEGALLY) a small number of
> plants for a few patients, and himself.
> Unable to show them paperwork at the time,
> Bob was arrested. Now Bob has thousands of
> dollars in lawyer fees, bail fees, and a trial coming
> up at $500 a day in court. Please, give to Bob's
> foundation and enjoy a musical freak out in the
> process. We are all better off with Bob, and
> people like Bob NOT in jail. Please.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] bsp - bob's story

http://www.rxcbc.org/

oakland cannabis buyers coop/club

awesome sight, tons of legal info n such. . .

Oakland/Berkely are pretty much the main activist areas in california. . .
OCBC turned from a club to more of a widely respected activism group after
all the legal bs they had to go thru years ago. . .

one of the (in not THE) best places to go for your questions and concerns,
legal issues, etc. . .also issue solid legitimate id cards  (widely
accepted, moreso than any other club) and run a 24/7 888 number (for law
enforcement use only) in case you're ever harassed by police or whoever,
where the officers are encouraged to call to have things properly explained
to them.

They also have email lists which update you on all sorts of current
happenings n stuff. . .

their office # is 510.832.5346

good stuff

: )

aK

Subject: [sfraves] re:  Bob's story


hi aryck.

no, i didn't take it that way.  i am not as educated as you on these issues.

my friend got arrested.  he told me he was legal.  i believed him.  he
needs money.  i'm helping him.

also, i had no idea that legal growing was as airtight as you described
it.  i was under the impression that it was up to the cops if they wanted
to arrest you or not regardless of "legal" status.  i was under the
impression that being a caregiver was a quasi-legal status.

after all, ed rosenthal is being convicted and i expected that at least he
would have all those forms and procedures taken care of.  i thought "well
if they (the man) can bring down ed then no one is safe regardless of
proper legal status".

i guess i was wrong about ed.

i will keep you informed. and i am doing more research myself.

i appreciate you.

sincerely,

Jonas

Received: (qmail 88620 invoked from network); 19 May 2004 22:11:01 -0000
Date: Wed, 19 May 2004 15:09:48 -0700 (PDT)
From: Dan Haskovec <dan@pry.com>
To: DJ Jonas Robledo <djjonas@sf-vibe.com>
cc:  <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <1069.209.150.183.210.1085003148.squirrel@209.150.183.210>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0405191505570.29011-100000@charm>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] re:  Bob's story

You're pretty safe from local prosecution, because there are state and in
some cases local laws that allow growing. However, there are federal laws
which prohibit growing, and the federal laws take precedence over local
laws. So the feds (DEA, FBI) can still bust you if they choose. Ed
Rosenthal got convicted in federal court, on federal charges.

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Coltrane drummer Elvin Jones dies

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Coltrane drummer Elvin Jones dies

NEW YORK (AP) -- Elvin Ray Jones, a renowned jazz drummer and member of 
John Coltrane's quartet who also played alongside Duke Ellington, Charlie 
Parker and Miles Davis, died Tuesday. He was 76.

Jones died of heart failure in an Englewood, N.J., hospital, said his wife 
of 38 years, Keiko Jones.

"He's happy. No more suffering," said Keiko Jones. "He's been fighting for 
so long."

Jones, called by Life magazine "the world's greatest rhythmic drummer," was 
born in Pontiac, Mich., one of 10 children. He had two musician brothers: 
Hank, a jazz pianist, and Thad, a trumpet and flugelhorn player.

Jones entered the Detroit jazz scene in the late 1940s after touring as a 
stagehand with the Army Special Services show, Operation Happiness.

After a brief gig at the Detroit club Grand River Street, he went to work 
at another club, backing up such jazz greats as Parker, Davis and 
saxophonist Wardell Grey.

Jones came to New York in 1955 for an unsuccessful audition for the Benny 
Goodman band but stayed in the city, joining Charlie Mingus's band and 
making a record called J is Jazz. In 1960, he became a member of John 
Coltrane's quartet.

Jones, with his rhythmic, innovative style, became one of jazz's most 
famous drummers under Coltrane. He can be heard on Coltrane's A love 
Supreme and Coltrane Live at the Village Vanguard.

After leaving the Coltrane quartet, Jones briefly played with Duke 
Ellington and formed the Elvin Jones's Jazz Machine. He put out several 
solo albums and continued to tour, including last month in Oakland, Calif., 
Keiko Jones said.

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

hello, we have a special song of the day and then we will be returning to our regular tedious project:
 
this is a spoof on a jessica simpson song (the one that goes "i want to be with you") that a lady might sing to her husband after she spends too much money on shoes on his credit card:
 
went strolling down the avenue just the other day
saw some stilleto heels that i loved
picked them up the very next day
 
chorus: i don't need noooooooooooooooooo shoes. cause i got these two-oo-oo
 
i wanna keep this shoes
cause they both have bows
and they make me look just like a straight up ho!
i wanna keep these shoes
cause the heel's so high
i can hardly believe these little shoes are mine!
i wanna keeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeep these shoes
i wanna keeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeep these shoes
forever
 
went strolling down the avenue
right again today
saw some pink heels that i loved
picked them up right away
 
chorus: i don't need nooooooooooooooooooooo shoes, cause i got these two-oo-oo
i wanna keep these shoes
cause they have pink straps
i don't have another pair of shoes like that
i wanna keep these shoes
cause the heel's quite low
and they have space for foot growth
i wanna keep these shoes
i wanna keeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeep these shoes
forever. :)

>Dear Friends; Please do not take this for a junk letter. Bill Gates =

you=20

Microsoft=20

will=20
